episodes.title: RTÉ Prime Time - "Scientology - The Return"
episodes.description:
From the RTÉ Prime Time blog, by Rita O'Reilly: 

Scientology has tried to make it big in Ireland before, but now it’s back with a multi-million euro investment in three new facilities – one around the corner from Government Buildings in Dublin’s Merrion Square, another in the suburb of Firhouse, and a third, through its affiliated Narconon group, in Ballivor, County Meath.

It’s an expensive return, but it’s not been a popular one, and indeed, it’s been marked by controversy.

What is it about Scientology? After all, it is tiny. Though it claims a membership of millions worldwide, the available evidence suggests tens of thousands. Here in Ireland, in the last census, just 87 people said they were Scientologists. The comparator often used is, ‘Well, how many people claim to be Jedi knights?’, and in Ireland’s census, there were 2,000.

Yet, its tiny membership has not deterred Scientology. It has said its investment has been funded by donors abroad. Its return is a big effort – aside from the new facilities, its spend is on outreach, with free events, Google and mobile ads, Promoted tweets, mailshots, booklets, and leaflets through your door – all material printed at its own distribution works in Los Angeles.

Why Ireland? Well, contrary to reports, we’re nothing special. Since the start of last year, Scientology has opened over a dozen new buildings worldwide.

They follow a formula it keeps repeating: its leader, David Miscavige and committed members fly in to the openings, which are staged events. Videos of those launches are then shown at annual internal gala events, where donor members are dazzled with special Scientology statistics promoting its claim of rapid expansion. Scientology calls additions like Firhouse, ‘Ideal Organisations’, and it says that Mr Miscavige “personally supervises the selection of each new Ideal Org”.

The weekend after its Firhouse centre opened in October 2017, Scientology launched another building in Birmingham, and the weekend after that, in Amsterdam: three weekends in a row – all staged openings, off-limits to the general public.

The organisation already has a Brussels office and its European headquarters is in Copenhagen.

Journalist Tony Ortega, editor of the ‘The Underground Bunker’, has reported on Scientology for over two decades. He points out: “The new Ideal Org in Dublin is not a new European centre or headquarters, it has nothing to do with Brexit and it has nothing to do with taxes. The Church of Scientology is already tax exempt in the United States, it pays no taxes; it is not looking for new tax shelters.”

But its office in Merrion Square, opened in 2015, is one of only a few ‘National Affairs’ offices it has. “These are moves that reflect what David Miscavige has done in the United States”, Mr Ortega says. “Several years ago, Miscavige refurbished a building in Washington DC for a new ‘national affairs office’. It was a new sort of idea for Scientology – they then extended that to Ireland. And why Merrion Square? Well, because it means a lot to Scientologists, that location, because L Ron Hubbard himself had worked out of Merrion Square back in the 1950’s.”

It was at the end of 1955, and Scientology’s creator, L Ron Hubbard was already a controversial figure. He had been refused a visa renewal to the UK, where he had a base, and he had temporarily moved to Ireland to what he called “the swankiest address in Dublin”, Merrion Square.

On 17 April 1956, while he was still based there, the Director of the FBI, J Edgar Hoover, noted that in divorce proceedings, Hubbard’s second wife, Sara Northrup, had described him as “hopelessly insane”. “His recent letters have been unanswered inasmuch as he is considered obviously a mental case”, Mr Hoover wrote.

At the time, (20 April 1956) L Ron Hubbard was writing to his followers that his Merrion Square office was a “British fallback point in the event of atomic attack”.

His stay was short lived: he left within months. His organisation, Scientology, however, set up in Ireland from the 1980’s.

Mike Garde of Dialogue Ireland has followed its arrival, decline and return since then. He says that though it is small, its impact can be devastating.

“I’ve been dealing with the families of people from Malin Head to Mizen Head in this country who have been affected by this Scientology organisation”, Mike Garde says, “breakup of marriages, breakup of families – of one guy, he became addicted completely to alcohol, they tore him apart”.

It is that concern and concerns like it that led to tonight’s Prime Time: ‘Scientology – The Return’.

https://www.rte.ie/eile/2018/1218/1017981-scientology-the-return/

episodes.title: Martin Padfield on BBC Radio 4
episodes.description:
Martin Padfield was a Scientologist for 28 years, after meeting a member of the group when he was just 19 years old. He joined the elite corps at the heart of Scientology, as his whole life became dominated by the teachings and strictures of the movement. But after he married, he started to question the way he and his new family were treated. He began to doubt the organisation's integrity, and embarked on a journey that forced him to confront the reality that his whole identity was defined by Scientology.

Martin tells Dominic Lawson how hard it was to extricate himself from what many consider to be a powerful cult, and how tough the journey has been to rediscover an identity lost from the point in his youth when he threw himself into the unusual world of L Ron Hubbard and his disciples.

In "Why I Changed My Mind", Dominic Lawson interviews people who have changed their mind on controversial matters.

episodes.title: Scientology ar RTÉ Raidió na Gaeltachta
episodes.description:
Scientology ar RTÉ Raidió na Gaeltachta le Rónán Mac Aodha Bhuí

R: Now, there's a lot of talk about the Church of Scientology at the moment - there's a new documentary film made by Louis Theroux about them, there's a ban on showing the film in Ireland; there's a new office open in Merrion Square in Dublin, which has drawn a lot of attention and talk; there's always talk about the big stars - the likes of Tom Cruise, John Travolta and people like that - who are or who were connected to Scientology. We have a man on now who knows a lot about them - Eamonn, welcome to the show.

E: Thank you Ronan, how are you?

R: Great, now, you don't want me to give out your surname on the show today, so I'll just call you Eamonn. You're part of the protests and demonstrations against the Church of Scientology, the Scientologists - why?

E: Yeah, I started going to the protests a few years ago. I heard and I'd been reading on the internet about all of the abuses done by the Church - they intimidate critics of the Church, they separate people from their families, taking money from people - so I started going to the protests and I met people who had been part of the Church previously and they had experience of these abuses, so that's the reason.

R: Can I ask you, why were you not happy to give your surname or those kind of details on the show today, to RnaG?

E: Yeah, well because the Church has a history of intimidating people who criticise them in the news. I've met people who someone from the Church spoke to their employer, saying they were a bad person, that they had done things against the law. And as well as that they often sue people who criticise them, they follow people. They have a long history of doing these things, so I don't want them to have this information.

R: Tell me about the Church of Scientology and their history, where do they come from - can you give us a bit of background please Eamonn?

E: They started in America in the fifties. L. Ron Hubbard founded the Church. He was a science fiction writer and he came up with a pseudo-psychological system called Dianetics and he started selling this system to people. He then formed sort of a religion out of this called Scientology and more people started coming to it. There are some famous people associated with the Church now, such as Tom Cruise and John Travolta, so they had a larger profile. They have an office in Ireland, they've had a Church on Abbey Street for quite a while now. I don't think there are that many members in Ireland - I think they say they have more than they do. As well as that, they've just opened a big new office on Merrion Square.

R: What is there to this religion. What do they believe?

E: The thing is - it's kind of part of the system. You go in and do these so-called 'personality tests' in the Church and you go in and do this test for free. They go in on the things that are wrong with you, that you're not happy with and then they sell you courses for the things that they find. The thing is, the beliefs, they don't tell them to you until you're at a higher level in the Church. The beliefs that they have are that everyone on Earth came from a different planet millennia ago and that we have souls in the bodies that we have and that there is a galactic overlord called Xenu that wants to put everyone on the wrong path. The belief system is there but they don't tell it to the public until you're at this higher level.

R: But maybe we did all come from a different planet thousands of years ago...

E: That's ok, if they have those beliefs, I don't have a problem with that. But the system around this, that you have to pay an awful lot of money to have your soul be free and at a higher level in the Church. There is a lot of secretism around it and the system around it isn't right at all.

R: So a lot of people are part of this system. What kind of strategy do they have? How do they entice people in? You mentioned this test they do on your personality.

E: Exactly, they do a personality test on you and they find out you have a problem with your family, you have a problem with money - oh, we have a course for that. Then, the first course might be free, and then they do what they call 'auditing' - you go into a room, you have to answer strange questions, they repeat things to you, it's a kind of hypnosis. Then at the end they say they have another course for you. This one might cost more money and if you don't have the money, you might have to work for them, enticing more people into the Church.

R: So they find out what the problems are in your life and then they try to get a benefit for you from that.

E: Yes, but the methods, they don't have any scientific basis. They're thrown together from different things - they say they're kind of an alternative to psychology - according to them, psychology is evil and only they have the right answers.

[Continues]

episodes.title: A visit to Scientology's Tokyo Ideal Org
episodes.description:
Across the country, donors and high-ranking executives say that the aggressive fundraising and construction scheme is used to enrich the central church at the expense of the rank and file, helping to grow the Scientology war chest to over a billion dollars. Two former members, Mike Rinder and Mark Elliott, went so far as to call the project a “real estate scam.” To some of these defectors, the structures are metaphors for the religion itself: garish on the outside, empty on the inside. The irony is that the very expansion that Scientology lauds as its renaissance is actually a symbol of internal dissent and decline.

According to ex-executives, the Ideal Org money play is simple: Find beautiful buildings; get local parishioners to foot the bill; keep them closed; keep fundraising; open them; and finally, have the parishioners pay for renovations, buy supplies, and send money to the central church for the right to practice there. http://www.buzzfeed.com/alexklein/is-scientology-self-destructing

episodes.title: 199 Problems (The OCA)
episodes.description:
The Oxford Capacity Analysis is an important part of Scientology recruitment and is used worldwide by the Church of Scientology to attract new members. However, it is not a scientifically recognized test and has been criticized by numerous psychology organizations, who point out that it is "not a genuine personality test" and allege that Scientologists use it in a "highly manipulative" and "manifestly unethical" fashion.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oxford_Capacity_Analysis

episodes.title: Jamie DeWolf on Newstalk 106-108
episodes.description:
Jamie is a 'slam poet' and the great grandson of the founder of Scientology, L. Ron Hubbard. To say that Jamie has things to say about his great grandfather would be an understatement. Jamie's grandfather, Ronald DeWolf, helped build Hubbard's Scientology empire in the 1950s but later denounced him as a "fraud."

Jamie's mother and ex-girlfriend have been visited by Scientology agents asking about his references to Scientology in his poetry. As he put in his own words -- "In high school, a psychiatrist asked me if I had a history of mental illness in my family. I had to say...YES!"

episodes.title: Flag Down 2014 interview on WMNF 88.5 FM
episodes.description:
Today on Radioactivity, we get a preview of a five day conference that begins today in Tampa Bay. The conference is designed to challenge the Church of Scientology and organizers say the conference, Flag Down 2014 will reveal the abusive conditions, financial exploitation, coerced abortions and broken families that lie behind the Scientology organization's veneer of religiosity.

Rob Lorei speaks to Pete Griffiths who was a member of the Church of Scientology for more than 20 years and one of the organizers of the conference. He also speaks with John Sweeney, author of The Church of Fear and a BBC reporter and Chris Shelton who spent 25 years in the church.
